description:
The image shows the structural formula of a monosaccharide labeled "Threose." The molecule consists of four carbon atoms arranged in a straight chain. The first carbon atom (from the top) has a double bond with an oxygen atom, indicating it is a carbonyl group (-C=O). This makes it an aldose. The second, third, and fourth carbon atoms each have a hydroxyl group (-OH) attached to them. Additionally, the fourth carbon atom also has a CH2OH group attached. The molecule does not contain any ketone groups (a carbon double-bonded to oxygen within the chain).

The label "Threose" confirms this is a specific type of four-carbon sugar. Based on the structure and the label, Threose is classified as an aldose with four carbon atoms.
